numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I have seen that wealthier students are more likely to get into college.
2. I have noticed that legacy students have a much better chance of acceptance.
3. This situation is not morally right.
4. This situation is a common trend in the graph.
5. I am curious about a legacy student who is not wealthy.
6. I ask whether a legacy student can still get accepted if the legacy student is not wealthy.
7. I ask whether not being wealthy reduces the chances of acceptance for a legacy student.
8. I ask whether universities accept more wealthy students.
9. I ask whether universities accept more wealthy students because wealthy students can pay tuition faster than students who take out loans.
10. Some students have superior grades.
11. Some students have a more remarkable resume.
12. I ask whether a student with superior grades can overcome the advantage of a family legacy.
13. I ask whether a student with a more remarkable resume can overcome the advantage of a family legacy.
14. This situation affects me.
15. This situation affects my community.
16. I know several students.
17. These students will be the first in their families to attend college.
18. My town is not wealthy.
19. Legacies are preferred.
20. I ask how these students will achieve their goal if legacies are preferred.
21. The rates may continue to rise at the same rate as the expected legacy increase.
22. If the rates continue to rise at the same rate as the expected legacy increase, my community will have a harder time.
23. I ask whether you got accepted into college.
24. I ask whether you are a legacy.
